sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on Jacksonian Democracy. The Age of the Common Man (1828-1840). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Thomas, age 15, son of a western farmer, 1829.

sections.section: Chapter 1: A New Kind of President
sections.narration: I'm Thomas, fifteen, from Tennessee. Today Andrew Jackson was inaugurated as President, and everything feels different. Jackson isn't from a wealthy Eastern family like previous presidents—he's from the frontier, like us. He's a war hero, a self-made man, someone who speaks for common people, not just the elite.
visuals: Chapter title: A New Kind of President

sections.narration: Jackson introduced the "spoils system"—rewarding political supporters with government jobs. "To the victor belong the spoils," his supporters said. He fired many federal employees and replaced them with his own people. Critics called this corruption—giving jobs based on loyalty rather than merit.
sections.key_takeaway: Jackson introduced the "spoils system"—rewarding political supporters with government jobs.

sections.narration: Jackson's biggest battle was against the Second Bank of the United States. This national bank, chartered by Congress, controlled much of the nation's money and credit. Jackson saw it as a corrupt monopoly that favored wealthy Eastern elites over common farmers and workers. The Bank's president, Nicholas Biddle, was everything Jackson hated—educated, aristocratic, powerful.
sections.key_takeaway: Jackson's biggest battle was against the Second Bank of the United States.

sections.section: Chapter 4: The Rise of the Common Man
sections.narration:
Jackson's presidency transformed American democracy. Before him, politics was dominated by wealthy, educated elites from established families. Jackson proved that a frontier-born, self-made man could become president. He spoke for farmers, workers, and western settlers—"the common man."

Voter participation exploded.
visuals: Chapter title: The Rise of the Common Man

sections.narration: Jackson's legacy is contradictory. He democratized American politics, making government more responsive to ordinary citizens. He fought economic elites and broke their monopoly on power. He proved that anyone—even a orphaned frontier boy—could rise to the presidency.
In this lesson, we explored Jacksonian Democracy through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Andrew Jackson, Jacksonian Democracy, Spoils System, Universal White Male Suffrage.
